WORST CASE RELEASE SCENARIO

The worst case release scenario consists of an instantaneous release of the entire maximum contents (up to 72,350 pounds) of the TiCl4 tank into the existing concrete dike secondary containment area with a surface area of approximately 372 square feet.  Assessment of the worst case scenario allows inclusion of passive mitigation systems such as the concrete dike, but does not allow inclusion of active mitigation systems such as Ferro?s foam suppression system.  

TiCl4 is highly reactive with water and generates HCl when contacting the moisture in air.  The worst case release assumes that the TiCl4 volatilizing from the surface of the contained liquid instantaneously reacts with moisture in air to generate HCl gas.  The rate of generation of the HCl gas was determined from the modeled volatilization rate of TiCl4 and the stoichiometry of the reaction of TiCl4 with water.  Results of the previously submitted Chemical Manufacturer?s Association (CMA) TiCl4 Dispersion Modeling System (as included in the original RMP submittal) were used to estimate the HCl generation rate.  It should be noted that HCl is not a chemical used in a process at the Ferro facility and is being included in this RMP under the General Duty clause.  Air dispersion modeling using the estimated HCl generation rate and the Areal Locations of Hazardous Atmospheres (ALOHA) software indicated that the distance to the HCl toxic endpoint was 0.19 miles (1,023 feet).  This results in an estimated off-site impact since the distance to the fenceline from the TiCl4 storage tank is approximately 300 feet.  Again, assessment of the worst case scenario does not allow for inclusion of the active mitigation system (foam suppression).  It is likely that the foam suppression system would reduce the distance to the toxic endpoint even further; thereby further reducing the potential for off-site impacts.

ALTERNATIVE RELEASE

SCENARIOS

Multiple alternative release scenarios were evaluated to assess if other more likely events would potentially cause an off-site impact.  Of the alternatives evaluated, two are presented in the RMP.  The first alternative release scenario was selected since it appeared as the worst case scenario in the previous RMP submittal.  The second alternative release scenario was selected because it predicted the greatest distance to toxic endpoint out of all other scenarios evaluated.

The first alternative release scenario included in the RMP is the previous RMP?s worst case scenario ? the instantaneous release of the entire contents of the TiCl4 tank into the secondary containment area.  This alternative release scenario evaluates the distance to the toxic endpoint for TiCl4 rather than for HCl.  The CMA TiCl4 Dispersion Modeling System indicated that the distance to toxic endpoint for TiCl4 under this scenario is 39 feet which is less than the distance to the fenceline (approximately 300 feet).  Therefore, no off-site impact is predicted for this release scenario.

The second alternative release scenario included in the RMP is the release of TiCl4 from a breach in the transfer line during filling of the storage tank, resulting in formation of a liquid puddle of TiCl4 inside the secondary containment area that is suppressed within 5 minutes using foam.  The ALOHA dispersion model indicated that the distance to the HCl toxic endpoint under this scenario is 369 feet.  There were no public or environmental receptors identified within this radius for this release scenario.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The TiCl4 process at the Ferro facility is in compliance with Section 112(r) of the CAA and the New York State CBS regulations. Chemical-specific prevention steps are included in the facility?s CBS Spill Prevention Report.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Ferro facility has not experienced any accidental releases of TiCl4 in the past five years (Janu

ary 1999-January 2004).

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Ferro facility maintains a Hazardous Waste Contingency Plan which includes emergency response procedures to be followed in the event of an accidental release of TiCl4. The Plan has been coordinated with local emergency response agencies, including the State Emergency Response Commission. The Plan also includes provisions for public notification in the event of a release.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Ferro facility currently has no planned changes associated with improving safety. In the recent past, Ferro installed a foam suppression system at the TiCl4 storage tank dike area to provide additional protection against off-site migration of HCl gas.
